questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following determines the sex of the fetus?
questions.explanation:
The sex of the fetus is determined by Yp11, which is a region present on the short arm of the Y 
chromosome. It contains the SRY gene, which produces the protein called the testis determining factor. This 
causes the gonads to develop into the testes. The target gene for SRY which favours testis 
differentiation is SOX9. If SRY gene or Y chromosome are absent, the gonads develop as ovaries. The genes that favor this 
are: • WnT4 • Rspo • DAX1

questions.question: Question 2: When does the sexual differentiation of the fetus occur?
questions.explanation:
Sexual differentiation of the fetus occurs only after the 7th week of development. The chromosomal and genetic sex of an embryo is determined at fertilization by the kind of sperm 
that fertilizes the ovum (X or Y). However, male and female morphological characteristics begin 
developing after the 7th week. At the end of the 6th week of development, it is impossible to 
distinguish between the two sexes.

questions.question: Question 3: Where is the lower part of the vagina derived from?
questions.explanation:
The lower part of the vagina is derived from the urogenital sinus. Option A: The ovary and the testis are derived from the genital ridge. Option C: The upper part of the vagina is derived from the paramesonephric duct or Mullerian 
duct. The uterus develops from the fusion of the right and left paramesonephric ducts in the 
midline. Option D: The labia minora and the ventral aspect of the penis are derived from the urogenital 
folds. 96 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: What is the vaginal epithelium derived from?
questions.explanation:
The vaginal epithelium is derived from the epithelium of the urogenital sinus. The epithelium of urogenital sinus is formed by the endoderm. ›ote: Urogenital sinus epithelium stains positive for FOXA1, and Mullerian duct epithelium stains 
positive for PAXè. In è017, immunohistochemical testing done on embryos revealed vaginal 
epithelium showed positive immunostaining for both FOXA1 and PAXè.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following structures in women is homologous to gubernaculum testis in men?
questions.explanation: The round ligament in women is homologous to gubernaculum testis in men. Homologous structures are those that have the same embryological origin.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is not a derivative of the paramesonephric duct?
questions.explanation:
The Gartner's duct is not derived from the paramesonephric duct. It is a remnant of the 
mesonephric/ Wolffian duct.

questions.question: Question 7: What is the most common developmental abnormality of the uterus?
questions.explanation:
The most common developmental abnormality of the uterus is septate uterus, followed by 
bicornuate uterus. 97 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: Given below is the hysterosalpingogram of a woman who presented with infertility. Identify 
the uterine anomaly seen. 89 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
In a hysterosalpingogram, the uterine anomaly cannot be determined as the external contour of 
the uterus cannot be seen. Hysterosalpingography (HSG) provides excellent information about the interior contour of the 
uterine cavity. However, it doesn't show the external contour, so it cannot distinguish between 
uterine anomalies such as didelphys, bicornuate, septate or arcuate uteruses. Transvaginal 3-D ultrasonography (3D TV-US) is very accurate for the diagnosis and 
differentiation of uterine anomalies. It is the first and only mandatory step in the assessment of 
the uterine cavity in patients with a suspected uterine anomaly. Pelvic MRI without contrast provides excellent delineation of both internal and external uterine 
contours. It should be reserved for patients in whom 3D TV-US is not possible.

questions.question:
Question 9: A woman with unilateral renal agenesis presents to your clinic with a history of recurrent 
abortions. You suspect uterine didelphys. Which of the following would be the next best 
investigation?
questions.explanation:
Ultrasonography (USG) is performed to confirm a diagnosis of uterus didelphys. Uterine didelphis is a congenital condition that occurs when the incomplete fusion of Mullerian 
ducts that form the uterus during embryonic development leads to the development of two 
separate uterine cavities and two cervices, each with its own set of endometrial lining. It is commonly associated with renal anomalies such as unilateral renal agenesis, severe renal 
hypoplasia, etc, and is often associated with recurrent pregnancy loss, preterm labour, 
malpresentation, and prematurity. 3D ultrasound, a non-invasive test, visualizes both the external (serosal) and internal 
(endometrial) uterine contours, effectively identifying anomalies. Hysterosalpingography (Option 
C) shows only the internal contour, making it unable to distinguish between conditions like 
didelphys, bicornuate, septate, or arcuate uterus. 98 
Sold by @itachibot The USG findings in didelphys uterus are two widely separated uterine horns and a deep fundal 
indentation. çaparoscopy and hysteroscopy, being invasive diagnostic procedures, should be reserved for cases 
where simultaneous surgical treatment is planned following a comprehensive non-invasive 
assessment of a Mullerian anomaly. (Option A) Intravenous pyelography is used to diagnose congenital renal anomalies. (Option B)

questions.question:
Question 10: A è4-year-old woman visits the infertility clinic with a complaint of recurrent abortions. Upon 
investigations, she is found to have a septate uterus. Which of the following corrective 
procedures has the best obstetric outcome?
questions.explanation:
Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum has the best obstetric outcome. The procedure involves the resection of the septum under hysteroscopic guidance. Hence, it 
doesn't scar the uterus and avoids the necessity of cesarean sections for future pregnancies 
improving obstetric outcomes. Metroplasty is the surgical resection of the intrauterine septum. This is done by approaching the 
uterus transabdominally via 3 methods: • ‘ones metroplasty • Strassmann metroplasty • Tompkins metroplasty All of these methods are not preferred nowadays as they cause uterine scarring.

questions.question: Question 11: What is the sequence of pubertal changes in girls?
questions.explanation:
The sequence of pubertal changes in girls is thelarche  pubarche  menarche. 99 
Sold by @itachibot Puberty marks the normal physiologic transition from childhood to sexual and reproductive 
maturity. The order of changes in puberty are: • Thelarche - It refers to breast budding, and is the first visible sign. It indicates the competency of 
the hypothalamo-pituitary-ovarian axis. It appears between the age of 9-11 years, and is described 
using Tanner staging. • Adrenarche - It refers to the generation of androgens (estrogen and testosterone) from the 
adrenal gland. • Pubarche - It refers to the development of pubic hair, and occurs usually 6 months after 
thelarche. It is also described using Tanner staging. • Menarche - It refers to the first occurrence of menstruation. Growth spurt usually occurs between ages 10.5 to 13.5 years.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following effects of puberty are not mediated by estrogen?
questions.explanation:
Pubarche or the development of axillary and pubic hair is not mediated by estrogen. It occurs due 
to testosterone in both sexes. Around 50% of testosterone comes from the ovaries and the rest 
from the adrenal gland. Puberty in girls involves breast development (thelarche), an increase in adrenal androgen 
secretion (adrenarche), and the beginning of menstrual cycles (menarche). Estrogen has the following actions during puberty: • Breast development • Development of the reproductive tract • Starting of menstruation (option D) • Increased fat in the hips • Regulation of pubertal growth spurt • Vaginal cornification (option C) • Cervical mucus production (option B) • Epiphyseal closure • Maintenance of bone formation - acts against parathyroid hormone.

questions.question:
Question 13: You are examining an 18-year-old woman and it appears she has mature adult breasts. What 
is the Tanner stage of breast development in her?
questions.explanation:
The Tanner staging of the breast, in case of mature adult breast, is denoted as B5. 100 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:

questions.question: Question 15: Until which age is the growth rate of boys and girls similar?
questions.explanation:
101 
Sold by @itachibot The growth rate of boys and girls is similar till the age of 10.5 years. The growth spurt in girls overtakes that of boys for 1-è years and reaches a plateau. In boys, the 
growth spurt starts later and continues for a longer duration. As a result, boys grow taller than 
girls in terms of final height.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 13-year-old girl presents to the OBG clinic with complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding. 
She attained menarche 4 months back. What pattern of bleeding would you expect in this 
patient?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of puberty menorrhagia. Menstruation tends to be irregular 
and often prolonged. Since the hypothalamo-pituitary-ovarian axis is maturing, initial cycles are 
anovulatory. Therefore, the pattern of bleeding is irregular. Also, as the endometrium is under the 
prolonged influence of estrogen, it gets thickened more than normal. Shedding of this thickened 
endometrium leads to prolonged bleeding.

questions.question: Question 17: What is diagnostic criterion for considering puberty to be delayed in girls?

options.a: Absence of menstruation by the age of 14 years
options.b: Absence of secondary sexual characters by the age of 14 years
options.c: Absence of menstruation by the age of 15 years
options.d: Absence of secondary sexual characters by the age of 1è years

questions.explanation:
Puberty would be considered to be delayed in any girl who has not started menstruating by the 
age of 15 years. Delayed puberty in girls can be declared on the basis of è grounds. These are: • ›o secondary sexual characters are present by 13 years of age. • Secondary sexual characters are present, but no menses have occurred by 15 years of age. If any one of these is present, it's considered to be a case of delayed puberty. Precocious puberty is considered if breast development or onset of puberty occurs in children less 
than 8 years of age.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of short stature and absence 
of menses. On examination, breasts are Tanner's stage 1. What is the most common cause of 
her condition? 92 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of delayed puberty. The most common cause of this 
condition is constitutional. Puberty is considered to be delayed if: • Breast development doesn't occur by 13 years in girls. • Testicular enlargement doesn't occur by 14 years in boys. Causes of delayed puberty: • Constitutional or physiological delay (most common) • Chronic anovulation - PCOS • Anatomical: 102 
Sold by @itachibot • Outlet obstruction • Gonadal agenesis • Androgen insensitivity syndrome • Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism - E.g., Premature ovarian failure • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism - e.g., ˜allman syndrome Precocious puberty is considered if signs of puberty are seen in children less than 8 years of age. Causes of precocious puberty: • Idiopathic (most common) • Central • C›S tumors • Infections • Tumors producing • Estrogen • Testosterone • hCG • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia The protocol followed for evaluation of delayed puberty in girls is given below.

questions.question:
Question 19: A 16-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea has the following features. What is the most 
probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The scenario of a 16-year-old girl with absent secondary sexual characters, normal stature, with 
XX karyotype and high FSH and çH is suggestive of pure gonadal dysgenesis. 103 
Sold by @itachibot 46 XX and 46 XY gonadal dysgenesis without the phenotype of Turner's syndrome (short stature, 
webbed neck) is described as pure gonadal dysgenesis. It is characterized by the presence of 
primary amenorrhea with or without normal secondary sexual characteristics. Option A: Testicular feminizing syndrome occurs in karyotype XY. Secondary sexual characters 
are present and the uterus is absent. Option C: ˜allmann syndrome is a form of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. GnRH synthesis is 
reduced, therefore FSH and çH are low, and secondary sexual characters are absent. Option D: Turner syndrome is associated with short stature and karyotype X0. Secondary sexual 
characters and the uterus is present, but the ovaries are streaked.

questions.question: Question 20: In which of the following conditions do secondary sexual characters appear to be normal?
questions.explanation:
104 
Sold by @itachibot Secondary sexual characters appear normal in the following: • Imperforate hymen • Transverse vaginal septum • Absent vagina and functioning uterus • Absent vagina and nonfunctioning uterus - Mayer–Rokitansky–˜üster–Hauser syndrome 
[MR˜H] • Resistant ovary syndrome In androgen insensitivity syndrome, secondary sexual characteristics may or may not develop 
normally. The genotype is XY, however a female phenotype develops. These patients have 
well-developed breasts, but they have scanty body hair. This is because growth of sexual hair is 
only mediated via androgens. Thus, secondary sexual characters cannot be considered normal.

questions.question:
Question 21: A 16-year-old girl has come to your clinic with primary amenorrhea. On evaluation, height 
and secondary sexual characteristics are normal for her age. Ultrasound showed ovaries but 
no uterus was seen. Her karyotype is 46XX. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of Mullerian agenesis. It is differentiated from androgen 
insensitivity syndrome as follows: Option C: ˜allman syndrome is hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. There is a lack of GnRH 
synthesis, and sexual development is delayed. Uterus is present. Option D: Swyer syndrome is pure gonadal dysgenesis. The karyotype is XY and the uterus is 
underdeveloped. Androgen insensitivity /Testi

questions.question:
Question 22: 93 
Sold by @itachibot A 14-year-old girl presented with cyclical abdominal pain and a midline hypogastric lump. 
She has not achieved menarche yet. On examination, a bluish bulge is noted on parting the 
labia. What is the likely cause of her condition?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of an imperforate hymen, which has led to 
cryptomenorrhoea. This is a condition where menstruation occurs but is not visible due to an 
obstruction of the outflow tract. The menstrual fluid gets collected in the reproductive tract. When this collection occurs in the 
vagina, it is known as hematocolpos. If the collection extends to the uterus, it is known as 
hematometra. The collection of blood in the fallopian tubes is called hematosalpinx. The most common causes of cryptomenorrhea are: • Intact/imperforate hymen - a bluish convex bulge is seen. • Transverse vaginal septum - a pinkish concave covering is seen Ultrasound pelvis confirms the diagnosis. Management: Imperforate hymen - A simple cruciate incision of the hymen allows the free drainage of the 
collected menstrual blood, and leads to normal reproductive function. 106 
Sold by @itachibot Transverse vaginal septum - Extensive dissection and vaginoplasty is required. Option A: Bartholin's cyst appears as a swelling on the inner side of the labia majora. çarger cysts 
can bulge across the introitus. Small cysts can remain asymptomatic. Option D: Endometriomas are endometriotic lesions seen on the ovary. They present as adnexal 
masses. Endometriosis is a complication in cryptomenorrhea, due to retrograde menstruation.

questions.question:
Question 23: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother with complaints of failure of onset of 
menses. On examination, her height is 150 cm, her breasts are underdeveloped, and sparse 
pubic hair is present. Ultrasound shows a small uterus and no gonads are visible. Which of 
the following statements is incorrect about her condition?

options.b: çH and FSH levels will be low
options.c: Pregnancy can occur with ovum donation
options.d: Estrogen and progesterone supplementation is the treatment

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of gonadal dysgenesis. Hence, the patient will have high 
çH and FSH levels as it is a condition of hypergonadotrophic hypogonadism. Gonadal dysgenesis is the most frequent cause of premature ovarian failure. In this disorder, a 
normal complement of germ cells is present in the early fetal ovary. However, oocytes undergo 
accelerated atresia, and the ovary is replaced by a fibrous streak. This is called a streak gonad. There are two types of gonadal dysgenesis: 1. Pure gonadal dysgenesis: • ˜aryotypes seen: • 46 XX is seen in pure gonadal dysgenesis due to FSH gene mutation. • 46 XY - Swyer syndrome • Associated with primary amenorrhoea • They are phenotypically female due to: • Absence of testosterone • Absence of Anti-Mullerian hormone secretion by testes • The underdeveloped gonad ultimately fails, which is indicated by elevated gonadotropin (çH, 
FSH) levels • The presence of a Y chromosome can result in a germ cell tumor in the dysgenetic gonad • Treatment: • Hormone replacement therapy - with estrogen and progesterone • Infertility - Pregnancy can occur with a donated ovum è. Mixed gonadal dysgenesis: • ˜aryotypes seen: • 45 X0 - e.g. Turner's syndrome • 46 XX • 46 XY • Mosaicism • Dysgenetic gonad can develop into a germ cell tumor. 107 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 24: A 16-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea has come to your clinic. On examination, 
thelarche is absent. She has a normal stature, and her karyotype is 46XX. Which investigation 
would you prefer to perform first?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of primary amenorrhea. The first line of investigation in 
primary amenorrhea should be hormonal assay (çH, FSH, estrogen). Following this investigation, USG pelvis and MRI pelvis can be performed to enable the 
anatomical assessment. çH and FSH levels help to assess whether it is a hypogonadotropic or hypergonadotropic 
condition. The hormone replacement therapy is planned based on çH and FSH levels. The various types of hypogonadism are as follows: ›ote: In a patient with primary amenorrhea with absent sexual characteristics, the first line of 
investigation is hormonal assay (çH and FSH levels). Estro

questions.question:
Question 25: A è5-year-old female came with complaints of 4 months of amenorrhea. Her FSH and çH 
were elevated above the normal value, thyroid function tests were normal. Which is the next 
step in management ?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of premature ovarian failure. The next step 
in management would be to check serum estradiol levels to evaluate amenorrhea. Categories of amenorrhea are based on gonadotrophin and estrogen levels as follows: • Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism - also known as premature ovarian failure. • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism • Eugonadotropic hypogonadism Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism/premature ovarian failure is present when: • Ovarian function is decreased/absent - Serum estrogen levels are low. Serum prolactin is high. • çH and FSH (gonadotropins) levels are high, as sex-steroid feedback is absent. Differential diagnosis of premature ovarian failure: • Gonadal dysgenesis • Specific gene defects • Fragile X (FMR1 premutation) • Galactosemia 108 
Sold by @itachibot • Iatrogenic • Ovarian surgery • Gonadal radiation • Systemic chemotherapy • Autoimmune disease • Toxins • Viruses • Miscellaneous ›ote: Since FSH, çH, and TFT are already estimated, it suggests that all preliminary tests 
(including UPT) are done. Moreover, serum FSH and çH values are quite low during pregnancy. 
This is due to the inhibitory effects of elevated estrogen and progesterone. 109 
Sold by @itachibot Physiological Changes During Pregnancy
